Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story: I was halfway through helping my acquaintance, Mark, move boxes into his new apartment when my stomach started to rumble. He’d asked for my help last minute, and I’d agreed, knowing it’s what friends—or even acquaintances—do for each other. As we finished unloading the last box, Mark suggested grabbing lunch together as a thank you. I appreciated the gesture, but I knew the area well: only one small vendor nearby was kosher-certified, and I’d already checked that it was open. Mark, however, was eager to try the new burger place across the street, raving about their menu. I could see he was looking forward to sharing a meal, and I didn’t want to seem ungrateful or difficult after he’d just moved. At the same time, I felt the familiar tug of my Jewish identity, the commitment to keeping kosher, and the discomfort of having to explain or possibly refuse. The expectations of being a supportive acquaintance and a committed Jew pressed in on me, and I stood there, caught between the two, unsure of what to say next.
